articles.headline: Nonpartisan Tax Report Withdrawn After G.O.P. Protest
articles.snippet: The Congressional Research Service withdrew a report that found no correlation between top tax rates and economic growth after senators raised concerns.
articles.abstract: The Congressional Research Service withdrew a report that found no correlation between top tax rates and economic growth after senators raised concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Congressional Research Service has withdrawn an economic report that found no correlation between top tax rates and economic growth, a central tenet of conservative economic theory, after Senate Republicans raised concerns about the paper’s findings and wording.

articles.headline: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia to Lay Off Staff and Reduce Magazines
articles.snippet: Everyday Food will no longer be a stand-alone magazine, and Whole Living is being put up for sale.
articles.abstract: Everyday Food will no longer be a stand-alone magazine, and Whole Living is being put up for sale.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like many New York companies, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia had a difficult week. The basement of the company’s offices in west Chelsea were flooded by Hurricane Sandy, sending staff members home for the week and forcing the company to twice reschedule its quarterly earnings report, now set for Friday.

articles.headline: Fraud Case Delayed By 2 Months
articles.snippet: Caribbean Pacific Marketing appears to have become the first “emerging growth company” as defined by the JOBS Act to have prompted charges of securities fraud.
articles.abstract: Caribbean Pacific Marketing appears to have become the first “emerging growth company” as defined by the JOBS Act to have prompted charges of securities fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: In its prospectus, a penny stock named Caribbean Pacific Marketing proudly described itself as an “emerging growth company” when it began to sell shares to the public this summer.

articles.headline: Estimate of Economic Losses Now Up to $50 Billion
articles.snippet: Damages from Hurricane Sandy could be double a previous forecast, with economists warning that the storm could shave a half percentage point off the nation’s economic growth.
articles.abstract: Damages from Hurricane Sandy could be double a previous forecast, with economists warning that the storm could shave a half percentage point off the nation’s economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Economic damages inflicted by Hurricane Sandy could reach $50 billion, according to new estimates that are more than double a previous forecast. Some economists warned on Thursday that the storm could shave a half percentage point off the nation’s economic growth in the current quarter.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: FERC Takes Aim at Wall Street
articles.snippet: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission’s broad crackdown is aimed at manipulation of energy prices.
articles.abstract: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission’s broad crackdown is aimed at manipulation of energy prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street finds itself in a bare-knuckle brawl with a government agency.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Leader Ousted, Nation Is Now a Drug Haven
articles.snippet: Guinea-Bissau, the West African country taken over by its military in April, now appears to be a place where drug trafficking is approved at the top, drug trade experts say.
articles.abstract: Guinea-Bissau, the West African country taken over by its military in April, now appears to be a place where drug trafficking is approved at the top, drug trade experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: BISSAU, Guinea-Bissau — When the army ousted the president here just months before his term was to expire, a thirst for power by the officer corps did not fully explain the offensive. But a sizable increase in drug trafficking in this troubled country since the military took over has raised suspicions that the president’s sudden removal was what amounted to a cocaine coup.

articles.headline: Campaigns Brace to Sue for Votes in Crucial States
articles.snippet: Thousands of lawyers from both presidential campaigns will enter polling places next Tuesday with one central goal: tracking their opponents and, if need be, initiating legal action.
articles.abstract: Thousands of lawyers from both presidential campaigns will enter polling places next Tuesday with one central goal: tracking their opponents and, if need be, initiating legal action.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Thousands of lawyers from both presidential campaigns will enter polling places next Tuesday with one central goal: tracking their opponents and, if need be, initiating legal action. It will be a kind of Spy vs. Spy.

articles.headline: Latest Jobs Report Shows Persistent Economic Growth
articles.snippet: The Labor Department’s last pre-election figures showed 171,000 jobs added in October. Unemployment edged up to 7.9 percent.
articles.abstract: The Labor Department’s last pre-election figures showed 171,000 jobs added in October. Unemployment edged up to 7.9 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American job market is looking a little stronger than had been feared just a few months ago, according to the government’s final labor snapshot before the presidential election.

articles.headline: Comparing the Tax Bite With Obama and Romney
articles.snippet: What federal tax rate would you pay if Mitt Romney were elected president? And what would it be under President Obama’s proposal? How would that stack up against the richest Americans?
articles.abstract: What federal tax rate would you pay if Mitt Romney were elected president? And what would it be under President Obama’s proposal? How would that stack up against the richest Americans?
articles.lead_paragraph: What federal tax rate would you pay if Mitt Romney were elected president? And what would it be if Barack Obama were re-elected, assuming Congress goes along with the candidates’ proposals?
